newsitem.title: USA: Turbulence forces emergency landing in NYC.
newsitem.headline: Turbulence forces emergency landing in NYC.

text.p: Heavy turbulence over the Atlantic Ocean forced an American Airlines jet to make an emergency landing Tuesday at New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport, officials said.
Four flight attendants and two passengers suffered injuries, all of them believed to be minor, said John Hotard, an American Airlines spokesman in Fort Worth, Texas.
American Airlines Flight 2009 took off from Philadelphia at 7:40 a.m. bound for San Juan, Puerto Rico, with 256 passengers on board, Hotard said.

Thirty-one minutes into the flight, as the plane was flying over the ocean at an altitude of 33,000 feet, it struck a patch of what pilots call "clear air turbulence," Hotard said. There had been no report of rough air in the area, and the sky was clear, he said.
The pilot declared an emergency and landed at Kennedy at 9:49 a.m., he said.
American Airlines is a unit of AMR Corp.
